items.title: Could Canada join Eurovision Song Contest? Experts say audience needed
items.description: The federal budget included a line that said the government was working with CBC/Radio Canada to explore the possibility of Canada entering the Eurovision Song Contest.

items.title: Federal budget commits $1B to Arctic Infrastructure Fund
items.description: The budget proposes $1 billion over four years for Transport Canada to invest in major transportation projects in the North, including airports, seaports, all-season roads and highways, for both civilian and military use. CBC News speaks with former army commander Andrew Leslie for more.

items.title: Old caves yield new secrets from Canadians who went over the top at Vimy Ridge
items.description: A hidden archive of what for many were last thoughts and tributes to Canada is emerging from the soft chalk tunnels beneath the Vimy Ridge battlefield more than a century after they were created.

items.title: Could a rise in Indigenous-led developments move the needle on Canada's housing shortage?
Canada could face ‘worst kind’ of flu season as experts warn evolving strain may be mismatch for vaccine
items.description: With flu cases now rising in Canada, medical experts are bracing for a difficult influenza season linked to the global spread of an evolving H3N2 strain that could be a mismatch for this year’s vaccine.

items.title: N.S. Supreme Court chief justice defends staff poppy ban in some courtrooms
items.description: Chief justice of the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia notes banning court staff from wearing of poppies is 'very sensitive,' but said there can be 'no signs of favouritism' in court.

items.title: Chief judges back court poppy ban after backlash
items.description: The heads of Nova Scotia's supreme and provincial courts are expressing their support for judges who ban court staff from pinning poppies to their robes during proceedings after some Canadian politicians called the practice wrong.

items.title: What’s in the federal budget for you? Your questions answered
items.description: Many Canadians wrote to us asking what they should be looking for in the new federal budget. CBC News’ Catherine Cullen and J.P. Tasker are here to help break down what is – and isn’t – in the budget.

items.title: Manitoba Government Honours Indigenous Veterans and Supports First-Annual Powwow
The journey toward an expanded Port of Churchill has only just begun
items.description: Compared to  other major projects  granted "national importance" status by Mark Carney’s Liberal government, the proposed expansion of the Port of Churchill is still a very fuzzy idea.

items.title: After fuel spill in B.C. lake, early tests show no contamination above drinking water guidelines
items.description: B.C. officials say that preliminary tests show no contamination above drinking water guidelines after 80,000 litres of fuel was spilled into Kamloops Lake following a train derailment.

items.title: Southern Ontario, parts of Quebec see 1st snowfall of the season
items.description: Snow is falling on parts of southern Ontario and southern and central Quebec on Sunday with the potential for some regions to see up to 20 centimetres of snow.

items.title: Accessibility is coming to playgrounds in Regina
items.description: Sarah Turnbull isn't just a city councillor, but also a mother, and she's looking to make a change when it comes to accessible parks in Regina.

items.title: Advocates concerned temporary immigration cuts don't address systemic issues
Margaret Atwood is finally calling people out in her new memoir
items.description: Does Margaret Atwood hold a grudge? 'I don't have a choice. I'm a Scorpio,' the celebrated Canadian novelist tells The Current in an interview about her new memoir Book of Lives.

items.title: How one North Vancouver school is redefining education for neurodiverse learners in B.C.
Nield thrilled to help gambling Riders beat Lions
items.description: Touchdown Tommy Nield is going to the Grey Cup again -- and this time he's taking the Saskatchewan Roughriders with him.

items.title: Roughriders off to Grey Cup after beating Lions
items.description: Tommy Nield's three-yard touchdown reception with 11 seconds left in the fourth quarter lifted the Saskatchewan Roughriders to a 24-21 victory over the B.C. Lions in the West Division final Saturday, sending the Riders to the Grey Cup.

items.title: Riders score late TD to down Lions, punch ticket to Grey Cup
items.description: The Saskatchewan defence forced back-to-back two-and-out possessions to give their offence an opportunity to win the game.
